team.members: *Kaiming He, *Ross Girshick, Ilija Radosavovic, Georgia Gkioxari, Piotr Dollár (* denotes equal first authorship); Facebook AI Research
team.name: FAIR Mask R-CNN

description: Our entry is built upon the following papers developed at FAIR: (i) Mask R-CNN [1], for bbox and mask prediction; (ii) Feature Pyramid Networks (FPN) [2], and (iii) ResNeXt [3] 152-32x8d pre-trained on ImageNet-5k as in [3], as the backbone. No data labeled with boxes or masks, beyond what is provided in COCO, are used in our entry. No data other than ImageNet-5k were used for network pre-training. Main results on test-dev include: (i) Single-model without test-time augmentation: 45.5 bbox AP and 40.8 mask AP, which runs at 3 FPS on an NVIDIA P100 GPU while predicting both boxes and masks (ii) Single-model with test-time augmentation (multi-scale testing and horizontal image flipping): 47.9 bbox AP and 42.6 mask AP (iii) Ensembling of Mask R-CNN models for the competition: 49.5 bbox AP and 43.5 mask AP (3 models); 50.3 bbox AP and 43.8 mask AP (30 models). We will release our codebase ("Detectron") which includes Mask R-CNN, FPN, and ResNeXt. [1] https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06870 [2] https://arxiv.org/abs/1612.03144 [3] https://arxiv.org/abs/1611.05431
This method uses FCIS method to generate the initial results, and then refines the results by revising the region and the corresponding class.

team.members: Ruixuan Luo*, Borui Jiang*, Tete Xiao*, Chao Peng*, Yuning Jiang, Zeming Li, Xiangyu Zhang, Gang Yu, Jian Sun (* indicates equal contribution); Megvii Research
team.name: Megvii (Face++)

description: We first trained a modified Mask-RCNN[1] with context modules. Then, we chopped the detection branch and inserted four more layers into mask branch. The new mask branch was randomly initialized thereafter and the whole network was fine-tuned with sophisticated regression target of mask branch. For both training stages, we used very large batch size via synchronized parallel training (up to 40 GPUs) on Megvii (Face++)’s large-scale deep learning framework, MegBrain. We did not use the MSCOCO provided unlabeled images or other training data. At test time multi-scale and horizontal flip were applied. The single model achieved 45.0 mAP on minival set. The final result was obtained by the ensemble of two networks. [1] Kaiming He, Georgia Gkioxari, Piotr Dollar, Ross Girshick. Mask RCNN. ICCV 2017.
A single model doing simultaneous detection and segmentation based on VGGNet.
rfcn+mask; dataset: coco 2014 2017 train+val, pre-trained resnet model.

team.members: Haozhi Qi, Zheng Zhang, Bin Xiao, Han Hu, Bowen Cheng, Yichen Wei, Jifeng Dai (Microsoft Research Asia)
team.name: MSRA

description: The entry is based on Deformable ConvNets [1] and Xception network [2]. The deformable convolution and deformable RoI pooling modules introduced in [1] can effectively enhance the transformation modeling capacity of ConvNets. The new modules can readily replace their plain counterparts in existing ConvNets and can be easily trained end-to-end by standard back-propagation, giving rise to Deformable ConvNets. On top of a strong baseline (Xception + FPN [3] + SoftNMS [4]), Deformable ConvNets boost the mAP by a clear margin (~3%). In the entry, ImageNet classification is the only external data utilized for network pretraining. The single model performance of Deformable ConvNets is 48.5% (with Xception + FPN + SoftNMS). The final entry utilize an ensemble of 6 models. [1] Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei. "Deformable Convolutional Networks". In ICCV 2017. [2] François Chollet. “Xception: Deep Learning with Depthwise Separable Convolutions”. In CVPR 2017. [3] Tsung-Yi Lin, Piotr Dollár, Ross Girshick, Kaiming He, Bharath Hariharan, Serge Belongie. "Feature Pyramid Networks for Object Detection". In CVPR 2017. [4] Navaneeth Bodla, Bharat Singh, Rama Chellappa, Larry S. Davis. “Soft-NMS -- Improving Object Detection With One Line of Code”. In ICCV 2017. URL: https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.06211 https://github.com/msracver/Deformable-ConvNets

team.members: Peng Xu, Institute of Computer Science & Technology, Peking University, Beijing, China; Gu Wang, Department of Automation, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Jialin Wu, Department of Automation, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; Qian Wang, Department of Automation, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China
team.name: Tsinghua-fcis

description: Our team has made three submissions to the test-challenge2017 evaluation server for segmentation mask detection. All the training data is from COCO 2017. The first submission is generated by a fully convolutional instance-aware semantic segmentation network (FCIS) [1]. The average precision of FCIS is 29% on COCO test-dev set, and the inference time is 0.1s per image on a TITAN Xp. The second and third submissions are generated by a deformable convolutional instance-aware semantic segmentation network (DCIS). The architecture of DCIS is similar to the FCIS, while some convolution layers are replaced by deformable convolution layers [2]. As the convolution layer is a special case of the deformable convolution layer, DCIS has all advantages of FCIS. With deformable convolution layers, the DCIS is more effective to learn deep features for the segmentation task. The second and third submissions are evaluated on different training epoch of a DCIS model. The average precisions of the second and third submissions are 27.8% and 28.0% on COCO test-dev set. The inference time of DCIS is 0.22s per image on a TITAN Xp. [1] Yi Li, Haozhi Qi, Jifeng Dai, Xiangyang Ji and Yichen Wei. "Fully Convolutional Instance-aware Semantic Segmentation," CVPR, 2017 [2] Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei. "Deformable Convolutional Networks," arxiv: 1703.06211, 2017.

team.members: Jaehyup Jeong*(Inha Univ.), Hunjun Yang*(Inha Univ.), Seungjae Lee(ETRI), Weongeun Oh(ETRI), Bowon Lee(Inha Univ.) (*Equal contribution)
team.name: INET

description: We trained variants of FCIS [1] with deformable methods in [2]. For ensembles, we used ResNets [3] and ResNeXt [4] as base networks and performed multi-scale testing. The ensembles consist of three models with the single model performance of 32.2%. No external data was used for the training. The inference time is 0.252 seconds/image with 4 Titan Xp GPUs. [1] "Fully Convolutional Instance-Aware Semantic Segmentation", Yi Li, Haozhi Qi, Jifeng Dai, Xiangyang Ji and Yichen Wei, CVPR 2017  [2] "Deformable Convolutional Networks", Jifeng Dai, Haozhi Qi, Yuwen Xiong, Yi Li, Guodong Zhang, Han Hu, Yichen Wei, arXiv preprint arXiv:1703.06211, 2017 [3] "Deep Residual Learning for Image Recognition", Kaiming He and Xiangyu Zhang and Shaoqing Ren and Jian Sun, arXiv preprint arXiv:1512.03385, 2015 [4] "Aggregated Residual Transformations for Deep Neural Networks", Saining Xie and Ross Girshick and Piotr Dollar and Zhuowen Tu and Kaiming He, arXiv preprint arXiv:1611.05431, 2016

team.members: Shu Liu [a], Lu Qi [a], Haifang Qin [b], Jianping Shi [b], Jiaya Jia [a]; [a] The Chinese University of Hong Kong, [b] Sensetime
team.name: UCenter

description: We develop a novel region-based object detection and instance segmentation approach by boosting information flow from across layers, iterative pyramid and global context information. We use a feature pyramid Mask RCNN as our backbone [1, 2]. Our contributions are listed as follows. 1) Instead of assigning object proposals to different levels by a heuristic metric, we allow each proposal adaptively to pick useful information from all levels, leading to improved information flow from across layers. 2) We augment another path from lower layers to top layers based on the observation that larger objects could surprisingly benefit more from lower layer features, resulting in improved information flow from iterative pyramid. 3) We augment the FCN-like mask prediction branch with tiny fully-connected layers, improving information flow from global context information when predicting pixel-wise mask. As a result, masks with higher quality are produced. Our models are pre-trained on ImageNet and fine-tuned on COCO trainval subset with mask annotations. We directly take the tighten bounding boxes around each mask prediction as our object detection results. Our best single model performance is 44 in terms of instance segmentation and 47.8 in terms of object detection on test-dev subset. We find that the performances based on Resnext-101 (64*4d), SE-ResNext-101 (32*4d), Resnet-269 and SENet are just comparable. We hypothesis the reason is that the limited GPU memory makes the larger models can only be trained on smaller image input which limits their capability. For ensemble, we used 3 Resnext-101 (64*4d), 2 Se-ResNext-101 (32*4d), 1 Resnet-269 and 1 SENet. With network ensemble, we achieve 46.7 in terms of instance segmentation and 51 in terms of object detection on test-dev subset. [1] T. Lin, P. Dollár, R. B. Girshick, K. He, B. Hariharan, and S. J. Belongie. Feature pyramid networks for object detection. CVPR 2017. [2] K. He, G. Gkioxari, P. Dolla ́r and R. B. Girshick. Mask R-CNN. ICCV 2017.
